question_text: How does the combination of shear stress and high pressure in shock waves enable ultra-fast chemical reactions in gasless inorganic systems, and what atomic-level mechanisms facilitate mass transport beyond conventional diffusion?
standard_answer: The ultra-fast chemical reactions in shock-compressed gasless inorganic systems are enabled by the synergistic effects of high pressure and shear stress, which induce plastic flow and atomic displacement beyond thermal diffusion limits. Under shock compression exceeding the dynamic yield point, tangential stresses cause material flow, displacing atoms from their original sites into thermodynamically favorable coordination environments. This plastic displacement, estimated at ~1 mm in shock structures, allows atoms to interact rapidly with nucleation centers. The mechanism involves nuclei of the new phase 'rolling' along grain boundaries, gathering atoms from both reactants due to stronger A-B bonds compared to A-A or B-B bonds. This process occurs in ~10^-12 s per atomic contact, far shorter than the ~10^-5 s compression duration, enabling complete reactant interaction. Unlike conventional diffusion (D ~10^-9 cm²/s at 1000 K, yielding ~10 Å diffusion length), this shear-driven mass transport facilitates nuclei growth to ~3 μm sizes, as atomic layers slide past each other, exposing fresh surfaces and enhancing reaction rates without relying on thermal motion.

original_text.2: Dremin et al. [2] estimated that for a plastic displacement of 1 mm (achievable in the shock wave structure), and the dimension of a single atom as ~2 Å, the time required for the contact between two atoms is ~10^-12 s. This time is much shorter than the duration of the dynamic compression stage (10^-5 s), allowing all A and B atoms 'passing' in the vicinity of 'rolling' AB nuclei to have sufficient time to combine with the nuclei.
